title: 106_s148
content: The Act is titled the "Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act". Congress finds that approximately 500 bird species in the United States migrate among countries, with many wintering in Latin America and the Caribbean. These neotropical migratory birds offer valuable benefits to the environment, economy, and recreation. However, some populations are declining, jeopardizing their long-term survival in the wild. Neotropical migratory birds are declining due to habitat loss and pollution, requiring international conservation efforts along their migration routes. Numerous initiatives exist to protect these birds and their habitats. Numerous initiatives exist to conserve migratory birds and their habitat, but increased coordination is needed to strengthen and enhance these efforts. The purposes of this Act are to perpetuate healthy populations of neotropical migratory birds, support conservation initiatives in the United States and Latin America, provide financial resources, and foster international cooperation. The Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act defines the term "Account" as the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account. Conservation includes methods to ensure the long-term viability of neotropical migratory bird species through population protection, habitat management, research, monitoring, and law enforcement. The Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act focuses on habitat maintenance, research, law enforcement, and community outreach. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act focuses on habitat maintenance, research, law enforcement, and community outreach. Financial assistance is provided under Section 5. The Secretary will establish a program to provide financial assistance for projects promoting the conservation of neotropical migratory birds. Project proposals can be submitted by various entities including individuals, corporations, government agencies, and foreign entities. Entities eligible for financial assistance under this Act include states, municipalities, political subdivisions, other entities subject to US or foreign jurisdiction, and international organizations. Project proposals must include the project leader's name, project purposes, and qualifications of project personnel. The project proposal must include a succinct statement of purposes, qualifications of project personnel, estimated funds and time needed, mechanisms for local public participation, and assurances of implementation to enhance neotropical migratory bird conservation in the US, Latin America, or the Caribbean. The project proposal must ensure local public participation, consult with wildlife authorities, respect cultural resources, promote sustainable bird conservation programs, and provide any additional information required by the Secretary. The project proposal must ensure local public participation, consult with wildlife authorities, respect cultural resources, promote sustainable bird conservation programs, and provide necessary information for evaluation. Recipients must submit periodic reports to the Secretary for evaluating project progress and outcomes. The Federal share of project costs should not exceed 25 percent. The Federal share of project costs should not exceed 25 percent, with the non-Federal share required to be paid in cash for projects in the United States and not derived from any Federal grant program. The non-Federal share required for projects in the United States must be paid in cash, while for projects in foreign countries, it can be paid in cash or in kind. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE SECRETARY. The Secretary is responsible for developing guidelines, encouraging project proposals, selecting proposals that meet requirements, and implementing the Act accordingly. The Secretary is responsible for developing guidelines, encouraging project proposals, selecting proposals that meet requirements, and generally implementing this Act in accordance with its purposes. SEC. 7. COOPERATION. The Secretary shall support and coordinate efforts to conserve neotropical migratory bird species by facilitating meetings, promoting information exchange, entering agreements with other agencies, and conducting appropriate activities. The Secretary may convene an advisory group consisting of individuals from public and private organizations to enhance conservation efforts for neotropical migratory bird species. Meetings of the advisory group will ensure public participation. The advisory group for neotropical migratory bird species will hold open meetings for public participation, provide timely notice, and keep minutes available to the public. The advisory group for neotropical migratory bird species will hold open meetings for public participation, provide timely notice, and keep minutes available to the public. The Secretary will maintain records accessible to the public, and the Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the advisory group. SEC. 8. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress by October 1, 2002, on the program's results and effectiveness under this Act, with recommendations for improvements and whether the program should continue. SEC. 9. NEOTROPICAL MIGRATORY BIRD CONSERVATION ACCOUNT. Establishment of the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account in the Multinational Species Conservation Fund of the Treasury to receive donations and appropriations for conservation purposes without the need for further appropriation acts. The Secretary may use funds from the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account without additional appropriation to implement the Act. Up to 3% or $80,000 of the Account funds can be used for administrative expenses. Donations can also be accepted and used for Act implementation, with funds transferred to the Treasury for deposit into the Account. Authorization of appropriations for the Act is set at $5,000,000 annually from 2001 to 2005, with a requirement that 75% of the funds be used for projects outside the United States.
